9.text:
Philip Bither: Hi. My name is Philip Bither.
I'm the Senior Curator for Performing Arts

14.text: here at the Walker Arts Center.

16.text:
We're lucky enough today to have Bill Frisell,
guitarist, composer, band leader with us.

20.text:
This is not your first time to the Walker.
I think it's about your twentieth or something.

26.text:
But on this occasion Bill is here with Eyvind
Kang and with Rahim Alhaj. It's really rare

37.text:
for us and I think even for you a little bit
to be someplace for a week to work on new

41.text:
music. And we are about three or four days
into it. How is it going?

47.text:
Bill Frisell: Fantastic. Like you said it's
so rare. The first day we just started playing

56.text:
we didn't have much of an idea. There was
one song that we had played together...

62.text:
Philip: A shortcut for one of Rahim's release
that he's doing.

67.text:
Bill: He's doing... I think it's for a benefit
for Doctor's Without Borders.

74.text:
Bill: He's doing a CD with all these different
people. That was more like a matter of minutes

81.text:
Philip: You met in a studio for a short amount
of time.

87.text:
Bill: It was also enough to know that we can
play together but we started with really no

99.text:
material. I didn't know what would happen.
It was just so nice to have the space without

115.text: the pressure where we could just play.

122.text:
Yesterday there was a point where we sort
of saw the whole picture of what the evening

131.text:
could be. We're still in the midst of working
on it but it just revealed itself that we

142.text: had enough material and we're feeling comfortable.

145.text:
Philip: Are you each bringing some of your
own compositions here together or are you

153.text:
I should mention that Rahim is a very renown
Iraqi oud player who comes from a very different

161.text:
musical tradition than you come from. I know
he's very respected in Middle Eastern music

172.text:
circles. He's lived here in the states for
a number of years now.

176.text:
Has there been a learning process around the
Iraqi maqams, musical structures?

183.text:
Bill: It's just too late for me. Even if I
start thinking about it I couldn't even try

200.text:
to go there, but with Eyvind, he's been studying
Persian music and there's a lot of the terminology

215.text:
and some of the language is the same. For
me Eyvind is sort of like a go between, or

224.text:
a translator for us in a way if we're dealing
in those terms.

229.text:
Philip: When did you guys first meet? How
did you...?

231.text:
Bill: I first met him 25 years ago or more.
He was a student in Canada, a volunteer. I

245.text:
played in Edmonton and he picked us up at
the airport. He was... I don't know how old

253.text:
he was, 17 or 18, and I thought he was a cool
guy. I didn't even know he played music. I

263.text:
remember he said, "I think I'm going to move
to Seattle." So then a couple of years later

269.text:
I moved to Seattle. I don't know how it happened,
but I saw him on the street, or something.

275.text:
I said, oh yeah, that's that guy that I met
in Edmonton, and one thing led to another.

282.text:
Philip: Now he's played in a number of different
ensembles, you've done collaborations.

286.text:
Bill: Just tons of stuff. So he's, for me,
just the perfect person to make it comfortable

299.text:
for us all to be. Rahim, he is just completely
open, it's not like he's expecting me to follow

310.text:
any of these rules, or tradition that he grew
up with. The whole idea is we try to...

320.text:
Bill: Yeah. I just can't even begin to understand
what's he's doing...

326.text:
Bill: Yeah. With these maqams or the scales,
and the way they fit together. I don't even

336.text:
know how many years, centuries... It's just
an overwhelming amount of stuff. Within that,

348.text:
it's like, well OK, I have my ears, and since
he's OK with me, it's all OK.

357.text:
Philip: And he said over lunch the other day,
that he too was interested in moving his forms

364.text:
and his compositional approach toward yours...
I mean, you meet halfway.

368.text:
Bill: Yeah. After I arrived in Minneapolis,
sometimes something will just happen, it just

380.text:
seems like a random thing, but I was on my
computer, and by accident I came across this

387.text:
thing, a song on YouTube. Tt was a Pops Staples,
from the Staples singers, just playing his

402.text:
Bill: Yeah, kind of a Gospel Blues; Ain't
nobody's fault but mine. Somehow, that song

412.text:
just grabbed me at that moment, and I think
it was the morning before the first time we

419.text:
played together. So then I heard something
in that song, and thought, yeah, the oud fits

430.text:
in that key. So yesterday, Eyvind and I played
that melody. In my head, I'm hearing, a lot

440.text:
of people have done that song. Nina Simone
has done it, and Blind Willie Johnson, Rosetta

449.text:
Tharpe. It has this huge American history
that goes way back. And I'm hearing that,

461.text:
and we're playing that, and Rahim is reacting

up to a brand new style of music, or a new

One of the adjectives that sometimes people

together, I've always admired how you are

And it seems that it always results in something

507.text:
over your history, where you trust yourself,
you trust the people that you've gotten to

513.text:
know personally enough, that you figure something

519.text:
Bill: Yeah, there's definitely, there's a
base of trust and confidence that I've slowly

529.text:
built up. But, I certainly wouldn't call it
fearless. Because I definitely have those

moments of complete panic. Not this one, I
don't feel it's somehow lower stress. I don't

actually, for the first time, at the Walker.

maybe music that I was composing and it really

happen. And, but that was... Having that chance

Bill: Oh yeah, there was a live concert with

for in the music, I'll go off on these not

But that project, I felt like it was a where
the roads... There was a number of roads kind

of came back into the... Like, I felt like
it was really like I was home or something

712.text:
Philip: You know, when I watch you perform,
and one of the really riveting parts is to

720.text:
see you in the process of, really, creation
before our eyes. And it's a wonderful thing

728.text:
to see as you're pushing a piece of music
forward, and trying new things, and it feels

735.text: like a kind of venturing forth before us.

741.text:
And I read somewhere that, you know, someone

749.text:
a structure, and you play something that you
really don't care for, and wish you could

753.text:
take back. And you said, really, that's not
it so much as you then... It's about the recovery.

759.text:
And you turn it into a plus rather than something
you regretted. It's maybe that mistake will

764.text:
result in something even more interesting.
Is that accurate?

767.text:
Bill: Yeah, yeah. For sure. And that's how
you... There's a Leonard Cohen... I don't

773.text:
know if it's in a song, or if it that I heard
Leonard Cohen say... And he was referring

783.text:
to making mistakes. But he said, "A crack
is what lets the light come in." And, I mean,

793.text:
that's so... whether it's been overused, I
don't care.

798.text:
Philip: Yeah, that's great. I hadn't heard
it before.

800.text:
Bill: I mean, in music, it definitely.. those
are the, you know, work so hard to get everything

807.text:
right, and then but so many things, I've probably

You grab something on the guitar that's in

824.text:
hearing it, it's like you know, you can surprise

sounds cool. And then you do it again. And
you really... I don't know. That's a great

843.text:
Philip: And that must come back to this idea

848.text:
Bill: Well, yeah. You have to be able to be

And where everybody's not keeping some kind

if things get turned around, or whatever.
It's not about pointing that out. It's about

everybody trying to make something out of

885.text:

943.text:
just seems natural to, wow, there's so much
amazing stuff. And it just seems natural to

954.text:
Also, the whole thing about the names that

that. It's just... It doesn't really... When

971.text:
those things... You're not thinking about

or rock, or country, or bluegrass, or whatever.
It's just... All those things come later.

986.text:
The words that describe it. It always comes

995.text:
Philip: Now, I think that's the universal

Has always been a resistance to the labels

on things. And so many artists have said it's

or more, is there a future for the music of

Philip: Yeah, and then started... you know,

or millions, of the same story. You know,

pretty soon I had an electric guitar, and
it's just...

it seemed like at that time... This was sort

It was the most amazing thing, both in music,

Whatever was in their wildest imagination

1328.text:

1336.text:
it excludes something, for me it was also

1369.text:

you. And I know. Was that something that you

1535.text:
oh, no that's not it and you just, it's just

from our limitations maybe then. Like, there's

on these talents that haven't been recognized

Bill: I mean, I'm not really thinking about
that at all. It's just, again, it's in the

2055.text:
world, and I'll hear somebody, I just want
to play with them.

2058.text:
Philip: You'll hear them at a club, or on
a record, or something like that?

2062.text:
Bill: Or we meet. There's always somebody
that I want to just... It's more like I want

2070.text: to learn from them. I'm not trying to...

2073.text: Philip: Do anything for them, or...

2076.text:
Bill: It's total selfish, you know. I'm just
looking to learn something from them. Yeah.

2086.text:
I've just been... I feel so lucky. Being in
this, whatever is going on with this.

2097.text:
Philip: Well, I think it's your openness to
hearing new things and new folks. Something

2107.text:
like you said, I think it was a year or two
ago, when you had just met Rahim, and you

2113.text:
said, Oh, I'd like to do something with that
guy, and it takes sometimes a little while.

2117.text: Bill: Yeah, it's took a while.

2119.text:
Philip: But then, there's a place to then
explore that a bit more. Is that how a number

2124.text:
of your collaborations, or will you pick up

2127.text:
me on a date some place, or a live performance,
is that how you introduce new people into

2134.text: your groups and things like that?

2136.text:
Bill: It happens differently. Sometimes it
can happen fast, or sometimes it takes a while.

2141.text:
Like with Rahim, I met him - I don't even
know, years ago, we met and kept talking about

2149.text:
trying to do something, and then it just gradually;
this was our chance. But sometimes, I don't

2159.text:
know, it could just be an accident, I'm trying
to think of an example, somebody gets sick

2164.text:
and I need to get somebody else. There's always
a bunch of people floating around, there's

2173.text:
a lot of people out there now that I'd like

2180.text:
Philip: [laughter] With your busy life, how

2184.text:
things, do you hear things online, do people
send you things? Where do you find your inspiration?

2192.text:

2199.text:
years ago, sitting around and listening to

2208.text:
happen, hardly at all anymore. People do send

that I feel so guilty, because I haven't been
able to hear it.

2222.text:
Bill: And now, everybody makes a CD. Anybody
can make a CD, so there's just mountains of

2234.text:
this stuff. I just can't hear it. A lot of
times it's actually not even hearing, a lot

2246.text:
of people I play with, I sort of knew that
I wanted to play with even before I heard

he played, there's this something going on,

2278.text:
when we met, and we met at the Walker Arts
Center.

sometime later, and asked him to play on the

2333.text:
Philip: You, like several other musicians,
I mean with Greg, you really forged an interesting

2340.text:

2347.text:
up through in becoming a master in Country
and Bluegrass music and things, and you went

2352.text:
the Jazz route, but you kind of complimented
each other.

2356.text:
Philip: And that he really grew up through
becoming a master in country and bluegrass

2357.text:
music and things, and you went the jazz route,
but you kind of complemented each other.

2358.text:
Bill: Yeah, yeah, and I just feel like we're
some brothers who were separated at birth

2362.text:
or something. But we really, we're close to
the same age, and our birthdays are exactly

2369.text:
six months apart. He's left handed and I'm
right handed. But it's just like he's... We

2378.text:
grew up with all the same stuff, with The
Beach Boys, and The Beatles, and Paul Butterfield

2389.text:
Bill: We all, it's just like bam bam bam,
and then there was that point where I... I

2397.text:
don't know. I heard Wes Montgomery and he
heard Hank Williams or something.

2403.text: Bill: And then we sort of came back.

and moments at The Walker was when we built

2415.text:

to come in the same day, and to share the

2426.text:
very generous. You and Greg came, and did

2432.text:
Philip: And it was just beautiful, hearing
you guys, just together, and really inaugurating

Bill: That was great and that was the first

2464.text:

"Oh, maybe this is something." Is that how

Bill: That happened that way, like sometimes

that I'd heard that song a bunch of times,
but I didn't even recognize it as the same

song. This Pop Staples thing, I heard it,

2507.text:
I realized that it was also on a Blind Willie
Johnson record that I have, but it's a completely

2521.text:
Sometimes these things will come up out of...
Like, Greg and I will play "Surfer Girl, " which

is the first actual '45 record that I've bought.
So there's stuff like that, I'll dig it up

there was in a coffee shop, "You've really

2568.text:
Bill: I've always, I haven't ever really played

Philip: And you did that recording, which

was from the John Hiatt song, but it was a

Bill: Yeah, and a lot of that music, it came

2593.text:
from old, my own memories, and then some of

2601.text:
a particular...like I played a Sonny Rollins

2609.text:
a memory as thinking about Sonny Rollins himself,

2619.text:

I never really played many, hardly any at

2634.text:
all, cover songs. I don't know if that's selling

2644.text:
Philip: Not really, because each of those

2651.text:
Bill: But, I mean, it was a conscious decision:

of the world [laughs] that I had come from.

Bill: I don't know if that's a low level of

2674.text:
Philip: I don't think so. Also, I remember

2681.text:
used music. Maybe not used it, but it seems
that a choice of a song relates to a point

2687.text:
in where the world is, and that we've just

2693.text:
really stresses, as there almost always are

2700.text:
first time, I think you were doing Marvin

2706.text:
Bob Dylan's "Masters of War" or "Hard Rain's
A-Gonna Fall." It feels like it's a soft way

2712.text:
of commenting on your concern around what's
going on in the world. Is that right?

2720.text:
Bill: Yeah, yeah. I mean, that music, throughout
my life, those are the things that somehow--I

2729.text: don't know if comfort is the right word, but...

2734.text:
Bill: Yeah. Just those songs, when we're in
those situations, somehow they help me. They

2750.text:
keep on being so relevant. Or you hear them
again, and it's like you hear the same words,

2760.text:
Bill: "Where Have All the Flowers Gone?" or
whatever, Pete Seeger. All these songs, they

2772.text:
Bill: Yeah. But then they're beautiful, too.
I don't know.

2780.text:
Philip: There's a few moments, other than

2785.text:
at the Walker that I wanted to ask you about.
Back in '86, your first performance here was

2794.text:
a collaboration with Jim Hall, who you had

Philip: And I read that you've just released,

2805.text:
Bill: Yeah. Actually, when we played here

2813.text:
I got out of high school, I met him. It was
like 1970, I met him, through another teacher

2822.text:
in Denver. And then I was lucky enough to
be able to study with him. I took like eight

2828.text: lessons with him in New York.

2829.text:
Philip: What was it about his playing that
attracted you?

2832.text:
Bill: Well, he was one of the... This was
at this moment when it was like this just

2841.text:
big explosion in my mind, discovering jazz.
Again, that word, but I don't know how else

2851.text:
Bill: Jazz music. And it was within just months,
I heard Charlie Parker and Sonny Rollins and

2858.text:
Monk and Bill Evans and Wes Montgomery, just
all these people, suddenly. And it was like,

2871.text:
literally, my mind was being blown. And he
was kind of right at the center of what the

2883.text:
Philip: Because of his innovative approach
to harmonics? Or...

2886.text:
Bill: Yeah, and it wasn't even so much the
guitar itself, it's the function that he had

2893.text:
amongst the people that he played with that
was so impressive to me. That he was playing

2903.text:
with Sunny Long's group, or he was playing
with Art Farmer, or Bill Evans. It showed

2911.text:
me how the guitar could... He was like an
orchestrator or whatever.

2918.text:
Bill: It wasn't just like some showoff. I
mean, he played amazing. People say, "Oh,

2925.text:
he doesn't play fast, " or this or that, but
that's completely irrelevant. It's more...his

2935.text: role in the whole group around him.

2941.text:
Bill: That sort of just set an example for
what, maybe I could do. And so then I was

2948.text:
lucky enough to get to study with him, I couldn't
believe it. You know, like, "Wow." I actually

2955.text:
met him. He's like this larger-than-life guy,
and he turns out to be this super nice guy,

2962.text:
and made me feel comfortable, and gave me
confidence.

2968.text:
And this is in 1972 when I took the lessons.
Then, about 10 years later, I was living in

2979.text:
New York, and I hadn't really been in touch
with him. It was quite a number of years later,

2984.text:
and I was in New York, and I was walking down
the street in his neighborhood, and he was

2992.text:
walking down the street, and I ran into him.
And I said, "Excuse Me Mr. Hall?" You know,

2998.text:
"Oh Bill!" and he totally remembered me and
was just super friendly and blah-blah-blah.

3005.text:
And then maybe another year after that I did
my first recording on ECM, and I sent him

3015.text:
that. He was still living in the same apartment
that he was. He still is now. So then, it

3022.text:
was suddenly like all this time had gone by
and he immediately called me and said, "Wow."

3031.text:
He was really impressed with what I'd done.
He said, "You were taking lessons from me,

3035.text:
and now I want to take lessons from you."
[laughter] "Now I can learn from you." It

3043.text:
was just incredible, the way he's just such
a generous person.

3049.text:
So, then it was like, "Wow, I wonder if we
could actually play together or something."

3055.text: You know, I never would have dreamed that.

3058.text:
Bill: The first time I actually played with
him in public was at the Walker in... Was

3065.text:
Philip: '86. Yeah. Which was... Do you remember
that date at all?

3070.text:
Bill: Yeah, yeah. It was just an amazing...
I don't know, it just was beautiful. Again,

3079.text:
him as a person, he's just been such an inspiration.
One of the things I remember, I don't know

3088.text:
if this is relevant at all. But for me it
was such an intense experience, just playing

3098.text:
the music with him and being on the stage
with him.

3100.text:
We played together, and then we finished the
concert and we went off the... Again, it was

3108.text:
another sort of a lesson for me. We went off
the stage into the dressing room, and I was

3114.text:
just so high off the music and just so into
that moment. We go into the dressing room,

3125.text:
and there's just like this massive... I mean,
maybe it wasn't that many, but it seemed like

3131.text:
a lot of people. My first reaction with these
people would have been, "Man! Get out! Leave

3142.text:
us alone! Can't you see that we just did this
amazing thing? And we need to have some..."

3148.text:
Bill: Because we need to be together and congratulate
ourselves, and all this. I was really kind

3156.text:
of pissed off that there was this mob of people.
And he just, he was so... It was just like

3162.text:
a little lesson. It's not over yet. You've
still gotta. And he just... He greeted all

3170.text:
these people with just... And he was probably
warn out and whatever else. But, it was like

3179.text:
the gig wasn't quite over yet. He talked to
each one of them.

3185.text:
Bill: In a real gracious way. And that helped
me, a little bit, too. I mean, it's kind of

3194.text:
Philip: Around that time, three different
times you then came back in various projects

3200.text:
Philip: The Spulane Godard piece. And that

but, the guitarists were Jody Harris and Robert

3243.text:
City. But the start of doing these more cross-

3248.text:
Buster Keaton films. That we, I think we presented
not at the Walker, but with Northrup. Across

3258.text:
Philip: And you started to explore some of
these collaborations with film and other art

3268.text:
forms. I think of that now having just a few
years back supported the Disfarmer project.

3275.text:
What attracts you to sometimes combining your
music with other media forms, or creating

3283.text:
it into a different context that somewhat
is more theatrical, and things like that?

3289.text:
Bill: I mean, I really... It's important for
me to write music and generate ideas somehow.

3300.text:
What I really love is just sitting alone,
and in addition to playing with my friends.

3307.text:
But, I mean, I love just the act of... It's
sort of like drawing, or something. It's almost...

3318.text:
I have a lot of cartoonist friends, or artists
friends. It's something about just writing

3329.text: music with no... It's just sort of like sketching.

3335.text:
Philip: So you do enjoy just, with music,
just writing music in note form. Without a

3343.text:
Bill: I remember, a lot of times it's with
the guitar. But also without the guitar. And

3347.text:
it's just sort sort of letting my... It's
an amazing feeling when your imagination starts

3355.text:
to go, and the thing starts to just come out,
and you let it come out. I love that. But,

3364.text:
what I was going to say about if there's something,
like a film...

3371.text:
Bill: Something, like a picture. That it has
a way of kind of

3379.text:
restricting you, in a way. It boxes you in.
Like, if it's a film, you have deal with time.

3387.text: Philip: And the action, or whatever?

3391.text:
Bill: Yeah, it's confining in a way. But then,
within the confines, I find that it helps

3400.text:
me to sometimes generate things that I wouldn't...
I'm saying, I love to just go off and let

3410.text:
my imagination run wild, but sometimes that
other thing will help me come up with things

3419.text:
that I wouldn't think of when I'm just left
completely free. So for me that is the most

3428.text:
attractive thing about film or writing or
being inspired by paintings or pictures, just

3436.text:
that it will get me to another place or somehow
it will inspire me. Just that one little extra

3450.text:
looking at a picture or something, something
might happen that wouldn't happen otherwise.

3457.text:

3461.text:
yesterday. One of the nice things about having

3472.text:
next door where artists can just take a break

3478.text: art collection or exhibitions traveling through.

3480.text: Bill: Yeah, that was great to get to do that.

3486.text:
Philip: You mentioned film and sometimes photographs,

3493.text: at times, or that you seek out?

3496.text: Bill: Painting, my wife is a Painter.

3503.text: Bill: I have friends that paint and draw.

3511.text:
Bill: There's a friend that is actually the
age my parents would be if they were still

3520.text:
alive. He was the first person that... he's
Charles Cajori, he's a painter in New York,

3530.text:
this is way out... is it OK if I talk about
this?

3534.text:
Bill: When I was young, my father worked with
his father at the Colorado Medical School.

3546.text:
He was the age that my father is, so right
now he's 89 years old, he's still healthy

3555.text:
and he's still painting. We would have these
dinners at my house when I was a kid, and

3563.text:
whenever he would come from NY to Denver he'd
visit and my father and his father would be

3570.text:
talking about some sort of incomprehensible

3579.text: Philip: Your father was a scientist?

3582.text:
Bill: Yeah, he was a biochemist. This guy
though was a beatnik painter guy from New

3588.text:
York, and I was like a young teenage. And
I would hang out with him. And he was like

3593.text:
"You ever heard of Thelonious Monk?". I remember

3600.text:
talked about going to the village Vanguard,
and he told me about all this hip cool New

3607.text:
York stuff. I didn't have any idea what it
was, but he was actually the first guy who

3615.text:
talked about Monk to me way before I knew

3622.text:
Then years and years later I just had a vague
memory of this guy, about maybe ten years

3633.text:
ago, not even that long ago, thanks to the
Internet, I looked him up. I said, "I wonder

3642.text:
what that guy...?" I knew he was a painter,
and he was in New York, so I look on the Internet

3651.text:
and it was like, bam, all this stuff came
out. So lets see... Whats it called? The New

3657.text:
York... I know its on eighth street in the
village, its not the New York Studio School...

3667.text:
He was one of the guys that started this New
York Studio School, and he was friends with

3673.text:
De Kooning. I didn't realize what all he was
involved in. But I found his name on the Internet

3689.text:
and he was still teaching at the school on
Eighth Street. I just thought "This is crazy,"

3695.text:
that I'll just write a letter. I just wrote
a letter and I brought it to the front desk

3703.text:
at the school and I said, "Is Charles...?"
And they said, "He teaches here one day a

3708.text:
week and I'll give him the note." I just left
it there and then somehow it got to him and

3716.text: he said, "I had no idea that..."

3720.text:
I said, "I don't think they'll remember me
but." He actually knew who I was because he

3727.text:
had come to see me at the Vanguard with Paul
Motion, and blah, blah, blah. But he didn't

3734.text:
connect that I was the son of blah, blah,
blah. I'm talking like 40 more years before.

3745.text:
So then I met him and he was... I'm going
way off the subject, I just have to tell you.

3760.text:
All the painters that he was associated with
starting in the early 50's.

3770.text:
Bill: Yes. My wife was with me and we were
sitting in Washington Square Park and he's

3776.text:
talking about crossing the street with De
Kooning and... I forget all the guys. And

3787.text:
the places he lived. I guess there's a picture

3799.text:
with Coltrane. In one of the pictures right

3807.text:
first solo show. So he was there every night

3817.text:
He was friends with Morton Feldman, and all

3823.text:
Philip: So he kind of introduced you to that
other world.

3832.text:
Bill: Yes. When we were sitting in Washington

3842.text:
the one thing I'm certain of is that drawing

3851.text:
thing, but there's something about that human

3863.text:
Like just as a kid I would draw monsters and

3872.text:
Philip: That simple pleasure of just making
something.

3877.text:
Bill: Yes. And it's something that not everybody
can or does, but there's something important

3895.text:
Philip: It ties us very much back to, what

3906.text:
of expect how these influences in life lead

3913.text:
happened to visit a friend of your dad's and

3927.text:
Philip: Yeah, it also ties to our role here

disciplines do have a relationship to one

3936.text:
creative music, painters and sculptors and

with creative music and those lines lived

Bill: Yeah, yeah and they would hang out with

4025.text: Philip: Yeah, Chuck came all right.

4027.text:
Bill: And then we started talking about the
Disfarmer thing and...

4031.text: Bill: That was sort of what we got that...

4035.text:
Philip: And then Chuck and I we joined in
together to help support it.

4039.text:
Bill: Yeah. I mean there's just so many important
moments in my, I mean I just want to thank

4049.text:
you really big time for, I mean I've said
that before but it's, I think, the very first,

4057.text:
when I first started to do my own music, taking
these little baby steps and being unsure of

4066.text:
what I was doing in the 80's or whatever else
and I was living in New York and I planned

4074.text:
a little bar somewhere, maybe but this was
and then I go to Europe. I mean Europe has

4084.text: been a place where things can happen.

4089.text:
Bill: But in this country, this is a pretty,
it's not pretty rare, it's like, it's very

4099.text:
rare and I've just had so many, the beginnings
of so many things have happened here it's

4108.text: just... So anyway, thank you for that.

4110.text:
Philip: Yeah, well it's been, of course, our
great pleasure and I think it's one of the

4115.text:
things the Walker tries to do. And it is really
one of the things that is so exciting about

4121.text:
being here is that it's just not about introducing
new artists or maintaining relationships with

4128.text:
mid-career artists. But really, with people
like yourself and artists like Trisha Brown

4133.text:
and Merce Cunningham and Ornette Coleman and
others, it's about really sustaining a body

4139.text: of work over a period of time.

4141.text:
Bill: That's the other thing too, it's not,
there are places that they want to have the

4146.text:
latest cool thing and you do that if you happen
to be in that moment and then they're on to

4155.text:
the next but there is this continuity that
can happen over...

4164.text:
Bill: Yeah, now it's frightening, yeah. Think
how long it has been.

4170.text:
Philip: Well, Bill I so look forward to tomorrow
night, and it's a pleasure to have you here

4177.text: Philip: Thank you, thanks a lot.
